job_title: Adjunct Senior Lecturer in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: As with most colleges, being an adjunct means you have a cap on classes you can teach and no real guarantees. Mercy has some of the lowest paying positions in the area, but recently they agreed, with the recently unionized adjuncts, to raise the pay a bit and give a few other perks. Teachers are usually there for the students so that keeps them (and me) teaching. I have a good supervisor, so am lucky. Also, the campus is quite lovely.
cons: No offices for adjuncts anywhere; there used to be a decent room to use, but since then adjuncts have been shunted to a basement space without windows. Not somewhere one of the faculty making up 70% of the college would meet with a student. Mercy had to have their feet to the fire to make any changes in what was previously the lowest per class pay in the area.

review_title: Non profit College turning into for-profit college
job_title: Admissions in New York, NY
pros: Colleagues -  Many of them truly love the institution, believe in the mission and care about the students.
cons:
Upper Management - The leaders of the institution have panicked and made many drastic changes.  People without admissions or enrollment experience are running the institution.  Leadership hired people with for-profit backgrounds who are treating education as if it was a car sales job. It went from recruiting students to the college to "changing" their minds. In addition,  it is now like a telemarketing/ car sales position instead of a counseling role. Remember it is a nonprofit institution, not a "sales" job.

Job stability - many colleagues quit right away and the turnover is unbelievable. Colleagues who work there fear for their jobs, but don't say a word. Hopefully human resources will catch on as more employees resign.

Pay - unreasonable pay for the amount of expected work

Miscellanous - If you want to be part of place where you fear for your job - this is the right place to go.

job_title: Admissions Recruiter in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros:
Generous vacation, sick, and personal time
If you have to work on the weekend, you get a day off during the week 
Easy to have a work life balance
Great job if you have little experience working in higher education to get your foot in the door
Generous tuition remission
cons:
The turnover rate is abysmal, many employees have been there a year or less
There is no system in place to train new employees, each campus does it differently
Only a handful of people have been there for more than a few years and they are normally in higher positions because of all the turnover
Assistant and associate directors more often than not are too young and inexperienced for their roles
Management is not supportive of their employees, they yes you to death when you have new ideas and do not follow up with them 
Salary is not competitive with schools in the area

review_title: Buyer Beware-- Appalling Place to Work (Work for Another College)
job_title: Counselor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros:
-- You may work with a nice and helpful team depending on the position.
-- Minimal amount is required to pay for graduate education.
cons:
-- The academic adviser (PACT), financial aid and admission departments are the worst departments to work for and have high turnover.
-- The management teams for each of the above departments are a joke.  They lack real leadership and know-how.  It is almost comical to see them in action (rather inaction).
-- They hire poorly and are inept in cultivating staff.
-- They promote based on unsound reasons. 
-- They browbeat the staff in producing fictitious results  (i.e. registration, academic progress, career, graduation rates etc.)
-- There is no advocacy for faculty and union members.
-- The new president only cares about registration numbers and passing poor performing students along to make the board members happy. 
--  PR outright asked staff to not post negative reviews on Glassdoor.  Read the positive reviews with a grain of salt.

job_title: PACT Counselor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Co-workers are great, campus is nice, tuition remission for those looking to further their education
cons: The pact program is poorly directed. The decisions being made are not in the employees best interest. The director does not care about his employees and feels that everyone is replaceable. Horrible employee turnover and the director does not care. Salary is bad. Benefits are average. The only way to move up at this school is to be good friends with the director. Education and experience does not matter unless you are friends with the director. And if you work at any other campus besides the main one you are isolated and treated poorly compared to those who work at the main campus where the director is at. The worse part is that you can't complain to anyone because the director is friends with everyone in leadership (human resources, union rep, deans, provost)

job_title: Assistant Professor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros:
School of Education growing and moving forward at a rapid pace.  Collaborative faculty.  Supportive Dean.  Do you want to publish?  Fulbright? Create a program? Research or write a grant?
The view at Dobbs Ferry on the Hudson is gorgeous. 
Campus is growing: currently building new student housing.
cons: Not too much to say that would be out of the ordinary.  Some students are under prepared for the expectations of the work.  There are always difficulties that come from working on a campus setting but the new president seems to be taking on issues head-on and moving the college forward.

job_title: Associate Director of Student Accounts in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: I started working at Mercy College in January 2019 and from day 1 I knew I made the right decision accepting the job offer. I’m an Associate Director, my Director is one of the 2 best supervisors I have ever had. She is supportive both on a professional and personal level. The rest of the staff works incredibly hard and has a desire to learn. I will be here for a long time.
cons: Due to lack of parking, two months a year non-union staff park off campus and have to take a shuttle. It’s not that bad, just stinks when you hit traffic. Also, entry level salaries should increase once someone gets a MA degree as an incentive to stop high turn over in entry level positions.

job_title: PACT Counselor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros:
I loved Mercy, particularly the can-do spirit of the students and many of the employees. My impression was that it is an institution that is determined to succeed and investing in its own learning as well as that of its students. They're trying a lot of new things, learning from their mistakes and iterating. It is a great place to begin building a career in higher ed.

Other pros: 
-Location, esp. the Dobbs Ferry Campus
-Tuition remission
-Lots of friendly, energetic, and smart colleagues
-President Hall is an inspiring leader
cons:
-Low pay
-Poor communication within and between departments led to avoidable misunderstandings (some of which are showing up in these reviews).

job_title: PACT Counselor in Bronx, NY
pros: I really enjoyed my group of coworkers. The campus is nice and has a variety of food options for lunch.
cons: The staff turnover rate is unbelievable, which allows for so much inconsistency within the workplace. The students can be very difficult to work with, particularly at the campuses in the boroughs. PACT counselor is a nice word for "the messenger". We act as the messenger in the majority of our roles and is no real room for leadership and creativity.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Meeting people / networking and learning the run around of higher ed is always a great thing and of course tuition remission which you still have to pay into anyway how ever thats it.
cons: There is no organization here at Mercy College. Especially for the ones lower end of the totem poll. Who end up being the ones who do most of the work for the college to function. They need to pay their staff more for what they ask them to do. It's equivalent to minimum wage. Absurd. Zero organization and other departments start blaming other departments for things not getting done properly which then leads to everyone stressing out and taking it out upon one another. Everything has become just a cluster of nonsense. Everyone is miserable. And not friendly what so ever!

job_title: PACT Counselor in Bronx, NY
pros: Helping students, variety of work since this position is the point of contact for everything, great place to gain experience as a recent graduate. Co workers are young, cool and supportive.
cons: The pay is so low but expectations are high. PACT Counselors are expected to do everything but do not get paid enough to do it all. Work is not distributed evenly; thus, academic advisors are doing admissions work and admission counselors are doing secretary duties which equates to a hot mess. Tuition reimbursement is now taxed which leaves no real benefits for this position.

job_title: Union Position in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros:
Forced to learn just about everything on your own, makes you more of a valuable asset to the College and future employers.
More responsibilities than is expected of your position, establishes an environment for constant learning. 
The employees (entry-level) make it worth staying at the institution, bonds are formed from the frustrations all employees endure while working there.
cons:
No support from upper management, no acknowledgment from employer, no room for growth unless it is convenient for the college.Transferring to a different department is nearly impossible if you are great at your current position unless of course it is convenient for the college (they don't tell you this but instead encourage you to apply to other positions so that you feel like you have an opportunity for change).
Overtime is non-existent, but they still ask you to work.... work for comp. time (the recently changed the name to "flex-time". Good luck actually being able to use that "flex-time"! You'' also be asked to "help" your boss on projects which is fine... however you begin to realize that "help" means they don't know how to do what is asked of them from upper management. The other aspect that weighs in as a huge negative, they ask you to train new hires... but don't see the need to promote you or pay you for a responsibility that shouldn't be yours... if you want a good laugh.... the turn over rate is so high that you may be trained by someone who has only been here for four months, six months... etc.. aside from all of the above comments.... great school to work for....

job_title: Associate Director in Bronx, NY
pros:
1) They tend to hire employees from non-traditional backgrounds.  This provides a great opportunity for career changers or new graduates to gain valuable higher ed experience.
2) Most campuses are centrally located.
cons:
1) Upper management can appear very removed from front line employees.  As a result many employees feel as if they don't matter to upper administration.
2) There does not seem to be any set guidelines for salary increases or promotions.  This results in discord as people with 5 years + experience are supervised by recently promoted employees with little higher ed experience.

job_title: Associate Director in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: My co-workers and manager make this a great place to work.  Ideas are always valued and we are encouraged to come up with new ways of doing things more efficiently.  I have never learned so much at a job and encouraged to continue learning either by attending conferences, taking certification classes or getting an MBA.
cons: I don't think there are any real cons of working here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Salary & benefits are decent, but this is NOT typical of Mercy College.
cons:
Most faculty in the department phone it in, if they show at all. Many aren't qualified to teach, and the students and other faculty know it too. If you say anything though, be prepared to be blacklisted. 

Department is run by a bunch of old, self-important blowhards.  Know very little about successfully running an educational department, seem most adept at patting themselves on the back for their 'successes' which consist of them talking about how successful they are. At what, I've yet to figure out.

review_title: Working through the fires of hell…
job_title: Student Services Counselor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Great foundation for working in education. Prepare you for your next position. Your next employer will get a superior employee.
cons: No respect for lower-level staff who do the majority of the work. No prospect for advancement even if qualified. Employees regularly have to train their supervisors. High turnover, staff are regularly snapped up by better paying institutions. Also students word  is always believed even when their is proof to contrary. This school needs to clean house starting upper mgmt. And pay their employees a wage that is comparable to other schools.

job_title: Assistant Director in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Work with a great staff that is highly energetic. They like to promote from within
cons: Pay,  nepotism and the turnover is really high.  There is a lot of group think and innovation is something that is lacking. They also put too much work on lower level employees compared to other schools and what they pay staff.

job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: This job offers to pay tuition plus stipend for every month so it is a good deal. The graduate assistant can attend some of the board meeting to create the value networking in future. The location working is in Downtown Manhattan 5 blocks from Grand Terminal so super easy to get there by Metro North train.
cons: They did not give you enough access to the school system to dig in more in your task due to confidential policy.

review_title: Reliable, down-to-earth, amazing colleagues and satisfying work environment
job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros:
-Treat adjuncts very well
-Professors work as tutors (rare) 
-Great, fun- energetic student body 
-Always get classes, semester to semester ... RELIABILITY 
-Great work environment, as no one breathes down your shoulder 
-Mobility -- campus interchangeability
cons:
-Pay is not so good, but you make it what it's worth. 
-Can't get more than 3 classes 
-Not much room to grow...

review_title: Prospective employees who want to feel valued need not apply.
job_title: Assistant Director in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros:
- You are given so much responsibility that when you leave you will be able to find a better job making at least $5,000 to $10,000 more.
- Working for this organization will make you appreciate any job that you get in the future.
cons:
1) No clear job description and time off schedule - When you accept the job you will be sold on the generous time off and holiday schedule.  Do not be fooled!  If you work in departments that require student contact, you will be expected to work most weekends and some holidays (including Winter/Christmas break). Some employees who are not unionized consistently work more than 35 hours a week (thats all we get paid for) and are not given compensated time.  Generally speaking, only if an employee works on the weekend will they be granted a day off in exchange. Also, most....let me repeat most employees have more than one job.  For example in a traditional higher ed institution if you worked in student activities that would be your sole job responsibility.  You may be assigned other tasks related to student activities but that would be it.  At Mercy it is not uncommon for most employees who are responsible for student activities or other jobs that are traditionally one person's job to also have a full student caseload and are responsible for that students with academic advising, career counseling, admin reporting, etc. responsibilities.
2) High turnover - Obviously based on what I stated above you can understand why this occurs.  Unfortunately this creates an unpleasant work environment, similar to that of a prision, where everyone comisserates and whispers about the things they are going to do when they "get out" and get a better job.
3) No respect for life outside of work - Once again you are almost expected to work beyond the 35 hrs a week you are paid for. (Just to be clear it is not uncommon to work from 9AM to 7PM on a daily basis in order to get all of your work done.) If you do not you are viewed as an employee who is "not dedicated" to the college and it will become difficult for you to get promoted, even if the work you produce is stellar.  Often times college events and other projects are thrust upon you at the last minute forcing you make adjustments to your personal life to accomodate work.  This includes holidays, often times non-unionized employees are given short notice (1 month or less)  and have to change Labor Day and other weekend plans. 
4) The administration rules Mercy with an iron fist, similar to a dictatorship - Keep your opinions to yourself or face the consquences of being labeled a "difficult" employee or one who does not have a "positive" attitude.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Yorktown Heights, NY
pros: Awesome coworkers that made it bearable.
cons: Worked in the Student Services Support Department, where we were expected to work in a call-center like setting while also serve as advisors, financial aid assistants, and Admissions counselors for little pay. They were not a student-centric organization but rather a money one. They would recruit solely for numbers and not for the better of the college or the prospective students.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Campus overlooks Hudson River. The students are friendly. The buildings are neat and clean. I don't really have much else to say regarding the positives of this job, just the beautiful surroundings and clean classrooms.
cons: They pay some of the lowest wages in higher education. Working there felt exploitative. Much of the faculty is adjunct. They simply give you a canned course from the educational publisher and leave you alone. No sense of professional community or development.

review_title: Low pay a lot of work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Dobbs Ferry, NY

job_title: Library Assistant in Dobbs Ferry, NY

GREAT BOSS AND WORKERS
Very fun place to work. Pretty easy because they let you do what you want as long as you finish your work.
cons: Not much to complain about. It's a great place to work. The salary is low but thats due to work study so not much can be done.

job_title: PACT Advisor in Dobbs Ferry, NY

review_title: Working here as a student worker was the best thing ever
job_title: Student Worker in Yonkers, NY
pros: I was able to finih assignments while at work. And not just that, working in the AV department helped pique my interest in AV equipment and its workings.
cons: None that I can think of.

job_title: Desktop Technician in New Rochelle, NY
pros: fairly relaxed college environment, good work hours for the most part
cons: occasional weekend work is required.  Dealing with VIPs.  scope of responsibilities is too great. nobody stays at this position for more than 1.5 years.  The college outsources IT to another company

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Bronx, NY
pros: The staff are welcoming and helpful, and I have found the students to be highly motivated, inquisitive, and respectful.
cons: I have found none thus far.

job_title: Math Tutor in New York, NY
pros: flexibility, I can't think of anything else
cons: salary, you don't get for more than 3 months in a year.

review_title: Something you want to forget like a bad dream.
job_title: Assistant Director of PACT in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros:
-There are so many job openings that you can get valuable higher ed experience.
-A free degree.
cons:
-Poor work/life balance.
-Certain programs get preferential treatment.
-Lack of transparency in senior management.
-Lack of respect for employees who don't go along with the "program".
-People quit so often its hard to get attached to your co-workers.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: President Hall is amazing, really has the schools best interest at heart. Fun events to mingle with other campuses.  Fun environment to interact with students.
cons: -lack of communication between departments

review_title: Keep your head down and you'll be alright
job_title: Research Specialist in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: No micro-managing. Got along with my supervisor splendidly.
cons: Upper administration - sometimes it seemed like they didn't know what they were doing. I didn't deal with them much, so it didn't effect me that much.

job_title: Student Account Representative in New York, NY
pros: Great benefit package. Friendly coworkers.
cons: No flex time, low pay for a great deal of work.

job_title: NY New York in New York, NY
pros: Providing academic instruction to the next generation of social workers with a focus on practical challenges in the current environment.
cons: Pressure to continually accommodate lagging students.

job_title: in Willimantic, CT
pros: Great learning experience fresh out of graduate school, became facilitated with the computer programs used in admissions department (higher education in general).
cons: No comment.  Prefer not to make any negative comments, it was a phenomenal learning experience.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros: They give you freedom to teach at the class's pace.
cons: The partially online classes have many students cheating.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Flexible schedule.  Opportunity for more hours. Nice team.
cons: Low pay, large classes and no tenure.  It's a nice place to get experience, but not for a career.

review_title: Not a great place to work

pros:
Dobbs Ferry campus
Mercy college merchandise
cons:
Too Low low of a pay
Hours
Management 
Disorganization 
Bad attitude of fellow employees

Office space

job_title: IT Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: Great Work environment. Friendly people, plenty of work to do.
cons: Needs to be more proactive when it comes to changes. Changes that will help prevent problems from occurring in the future.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Bronx, NY
pros: The students are motivated and eager to learn. Additionally, the administration is quite helpful and always communicative.
cons: I cannot think of any. I have greatly enjoyed my time.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Long holiday vacation with optional overtime
cons: The company does not care about the student. The are in the business to make money and could care less about the actual function of day to day operations. When it comes to Mercy College its all about the numbers.

job_title: Marketing Project Manager in Sea Cliff, NY
pros: friendly atmosphere that could aid learning
cons: not enough resources for students nor support for high learning standards

job_title: in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Amazing people to work with.  There's is always work that needs to be done gives you great experience.
cons: can be a little bit more organzied

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros:
good student atmosphere
good faculty contacts
great opportunities
great place to teach
cons: good office space and equipment

job_title: Admissions Recruiter in New York, NY
pros: great work life balance while traveling on the road.
cons: short time for training. must be good on the phone and not shy.

job_title: Tutor in New York, NY
pros: time flexibility. You choose whichever is better for you
cons: salary would be same forever. No promotion

job_title: Admissions Recruiter in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: A Flexible and enjoyable workplace.
cons: Pay is very low but aligned with the school's objective of maintaining tuition affordable for students

job_title: Adjunct in Bronx, NY
pros: Serves a predominantly minority student body
cons: Needs a more diversified faculty.

job_title: Front Desk Attendant in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros:
- Some positions will allow you to balance work and studying.
- Great atmosphere
cons: Most positions for students offer minimum wage

job_title: Recruiter in Bronx, NY
pros: Flexibility and a lot of time off.
cons: High turnover and new ideas are not embraced in admissions. Below average compensation for recruiters.

job_title: Instructor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Students are fantastic Students are conscientious.
cons: Students go to counselors first instead of coming to the instructor.

job_title: Instructional Designer in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Colleagues are nice and supportive
cons: Far from the city. It takes you about 1-2 hrs to get there.

job_title: Visiting Assisting Professor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Small campus, helpful faculty and staff.
cons: Was hired; a few weeks later no money to support the hire.

job_title: Data Science Research Professor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: As the title says, Mercy is laid back!
cons: Pay scale is on the low side.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Great team; Friendly team atmosphere; great benefits.
cons: Not a large endowment; tuition drives resources

job_title: Academic Advisor in Dobbs Ferry, NY
pros: Great people. Great environment. Love what I did there.
cons: The pay is very low.

job_title: Student Ambassador in Westbury, NY
pros: Ability to learn and grow.
cons: The pay can be better.
